metadata.titleEn: Cretaceous rock body data set of Dabie orogenic belt
metadata.description: The data include the stable isotope data of elements and metals of a series of Cretaceous rocks in the Dabie orogenic belt, as well as a small number of hand specimen photos and micrographs. X-ray fluorescence spectrometry (XRF) was used to test the major elements with an accuracy of less than 2%, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was used to test the trace elements with an accuracy of less than 5%, and multi-channel inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICPMS) was used to test the stable isotopes of Ca, Mg and Fe with an accuracy of more than 0.06 ‰. The above tests were completed from May 14, 2016 to June 19, 2020, The data have been published in many international well-known petrological journals, such as geochimica et cosmochimica Acta, chemical geology, etc. These data are of great significance for understanding the fractionation behavior of metal stable isotopes in magmatic rock systems.
metadata.instructions:
The file named elements, isotope data and image annotation are stored in Excel file, and the hand specimen photos and micrographs are all in JPEG format.
Data reading mode: Excel file can be opened by Excel software in office software. JPEG format image file can be opened with the image software of windows.

background: Iron (Fe) isotope fractionation could occur during crustal melting, which may contribute to the isotopic variations of granites. Our current knowledge on Fe isotope fractionation during crustal melting remains rare. High silica (e.g., SiO2 N 71 wt%) granitic rocks have a highly variable δ56Fe from−0.04‰ to 0.46‰, which has been previously explained by isotope fractionation due to fluid exsolution, fractional crystallization, crustal melting, source heterogeneity and/or diffusion. Migmatites are a mixture of metamorphic rock and igneous rock. They form via incipient partial melting in pre-existing gneisses, which is often induced by the breakdown of hydrous minerals (e.g., biotite) or influx of fluid. Produced partial melts that are siliceous and hence not able to escape re-crystallize to form the igneous part of migmatites, which are generally quartz and feldspar rich and thus light-colored and called leucosomes. The residual part of migmatites are usually rich in dark-colored amphibole and biotite and called the melanosomes.
research objective: This study reports high precision Fe isotopic data for a suite of well-characterized migmatites from the Dabie orogen, central China. With a purpose to constrain isotope fractionation during crustal anatexis, Fe isotopic data are reported for 23 migmatite samples from the Dabie orogen, Central China.
challenges: Our knowledge about Fe isotope fractionation that may occur during crustal partial melting remains rare, mainly due to the difficulty in reconstructing the source property and parental magma compositions for felsic igneous rocks, if considering the complexity of Fe isotope fractionation behavior during processes, e.g., fractional crystallization, after melt extraction.
methods: Iron isotopic analyses were conducted in the Isotope Geochemistry Lab, China University of Geosciences Beijing. About 2.42 –38.39 mg sample powders containing about 100 μg Fe were dissolved by concentrated HF\\HNO3\\HCl\\HClO4. Fe was then purified with AG1X-8 (200–400mesh chloride form, Bio-Rad, USA) resin in a HCl medium. The purified Fe was then measured on a Neptune Plus MC-ICPMS by standard-sample-bracketing, and Fe isotopic data are reported in traditional δ values relative to IRMM-014.
dataset: Migmatites used in this study are from the Dabie orogen, a Triassic collision zone between the South China Block and the North China Block. Thirteen leucosomes, 9 melanosomes, and 1 amphibolitic schollen from 11 Dabie migmatites were measured in this study.
findings: The leucosomes yield δ56Fe higher than their coexisting melanosomes by 0 ~ 0.36‰. After screening out the samples that may be affected by fluid influx and exsolution, fractional crystallization, mineral accumulation, and capture of peritectic amphibole based on Th/U, FeOt/Al2O3, and Mg#, 7 leucosome-melanosome pairs yield consistent Δ56FeL-M with an average of 0.093 ± 0.056‰ (2SD, N = 7). The leucosomes measured here have Fe3+/ΣFe ratios comparable to their coexisting menalosomes. Fe isotope fractionation during crustal anatexis revealed here thus is not dominantly controlled by distribution of Fe3+ and Fe2+ between the melts and their residua. Instead, it can be explained by the difference in Fe-O bonding conditions between the granitic melts and their residual mafic minerals.

background: Significant iron (Fe) isotope fractionation (e.g., d56Fe > 0.5 ‰, ten times larger than the analytical uncertainty) has been observed in terrestrial igneous rocks (e.g., Weyer and Ionov, 2007; Teng et al., 2008; Dauphas et al., 2009a; Williams and Bizimis, 2014; He et al., 2015b ). It remains unclear to what extent these variations reflect magma processes or source composition (e.g., oxidation state, mineralogy, and compositions) (e.g., Dauphas et al., 2014; Williams and Bizimis, 2014; Zambardi et al., 2014; Foden et al., 2015; Zhu et al., 2015a ); in particular, whether Fe isotopes can help reveal redox conditions of planetary and igneous processes (Dauphas et al., 2014; Williams and Bizimis, 2014) or whether additional factors, such as coordination environment, play a significant role (Sossi and O’Neill, 2017). Fe has two oxidation states (ferrous Fe2+ and ferric Fe3+) in terrestrial silicate phases. The mean force constant of Fe3+ bearing bonds is higher than that of Fe2+ bearing bonds in silicate glasses, which predicts an enrichment of heavy isotopes in the former and highlights the potential of Fe isotopes as a tracer of magma redox conditions (Dauphas et al., 2014). However, predicted isotope fractionation induced by the distribution of Fe3+ and Fe2+ during partial melting of mantle peridotite can only account for one-third of the observed difference between middle ocean ridge basalts (MORB) and the upper mantle (/C24 0.1‰ on d56Fe; Teng et al., 2013; Dauphas et al., 2014). In addition to the distribution of Fe3+ and Fe2+, the difference in the coordination environment of Fe is a complementary but independent mechanism of Fe isotope fractionation (Sossi and O’Neill, 2017). Among Fe2+-enriched silicate minerals, garnet with Fe2+ in VIII-coordination has a Fe isotopic composition substantially lower than coexisting olivine and pyroxenes, in which Fe2+ is mainly in VI-coordination (e.g., D56Fegarnet-cpx in eclogites down to /C0 0.42‰ and on average /C24/C0 0.26‰; Beard and Johnson, 2004; Williams et al., 2009). Accordingly, Fe isotope fractionation during partial melting might be also controlled by source mineralogy. Partial melting of garnet-rich sources (e.g., pyroxenite and recycled eclogite) may produce Fe isotope fractionation larger than peridotite melting and contribute to the high d56Fe end-member of ocean island basalts (Williams and Bizimis, 2014; Sossi and O’Neill, 2017). However, the relative importance of redox and coordination environment is complicated by source heterogeneity and Fe isotope fractionation during magma differentiation (Teng et al., 2008; Williams and Bizimis, 2014; Foden et al., 2015; Sossi and O’Neill, 2017). Observations serving as evidence to constrain to what extent source mineralogy can affect Fe isotope fractionation during partial melting, however, remain scarce. Adakitic rocks may help to provide these constraints, as they are derived by partial melting of eclogitic rocks with variably abundant residual garnet (Defant and Drummond, 1990; Rapp and Watson, 1995; He et al., 2011), and thus may provide a test on the role of source mineralogy in fractionating Fe isotopes during partial melting processes.
research objective: In this study, we present the first Fe isotopic data for adakitic rocks, including 15 LMA and 22 HMA samples from the Dabie orogen (Central China) and Panama/Costa Rica (Central America), to constrain the source mineralogy effect on Fe isotope fractionation during partial melting. Thirteen non-adakitic granitoid samples from the Dabie orogen, with SiO2 spanning from 56 to 77 wt.%, are also measured to better understand Fe isotope fractionation during differentiation of intermediate and felsic magmas and to constrain the extent of magma compositional control.
methods: Iron isotope analyses were conducted at the Isotope Geochemistry Laboratory, China University of Geosciences, Beijing. The chemistry procedures are largely after Dauphas et al. (2009b) and detailed in He et al. (2015a). Approximately 5–20 mg whole rock powders were dissolved in Teflon beakers in a mixture of HF-HNO3-HClO4, and then refluxed with aqua regia (HCl: HNO3 = 3:1) and excess HNO3 aqua regia (HCl: HNO3 = 2:1) successively at 130 /C176C. The solutions were subsequently evaporated to dryness at 100 /C176C. Finally, residues were dissolved in 6 N HCl for chromatographic purification. Iron was separated from matrix elements and potential isobars with AG1X-8 resin (200–400 mesh) in a HCl medium. Whole procedure blank is 610 ng and can be considered negligible, considering P100 lg sample Fe was processed. Isotopic ratios were analyzed by the sample-standard bracketing method using a Thermo-Finnigan Neptune Plus MC-ICPMS on high resolution modes. The isotopic measurement sequence was repeated nine times for each sample Fe solution to get better accuracy, and the data are reported in the traditional d values relative to IRMM-014 (diFe = [(iFe/54Fe)sample/(iFe/54-Fe)IRMM-014 /C0 1] /C2 1000, where i can be 56 or 57). Two standard errors of the mean are reported after Dauphas et al. (2009b) and He et al. (2015a), with consideration of those arising both from chemical procedures and from the MC-ICPMS measurement. Based on totally > 300 duplicate measurements on 23 geological standards with different matrices, the long-term external reproducibility and accuracy on d56Fe are estimated to be better than ±0.03 ‰ (2SD) (He et al., 2015a).
dataset: The samples investigated in this study include 39 Early Cretaceous granitoids from the Dabie orogen, Central China (Fig. S1) and 11 adakites and 1 basaltic oceanic crust sample from Costa Rica and Panama, Central America (Fig. S2).
findings: I-type Dabie non-adakitic granitoids yield d56Fe ranging from /C0 0.015‰ to 0.184 ‰. One A-type granite sample from the Dabie orogen has d56Fe as high as 0.447 ‰, which cannot be explained by the same fractional crystallization trends defined by I-type samples but requires higher integrated D56Femelt-crystal. Except for one sample that may have been significantly changed by fractional crystallization, d56Fe of Dabie LMA varies from 0.114 ‰ to 0.234 ‰ and increases with increasing (Dy/Yb) N. High-Mg adakites from the Dabie orogen and Central America both have homogeneous Fe isotopic compositions with a mean d56Fe /C24 0.10‰.

background: Garnet that has a distinctly light Mg isotopic composition compared to other maﬁc minerals is commonly present in deep crustal and mantle sources. These LMA are known for derivation from maﬁc sources leaving eclogitic residua with variable abundance of garnet.
research objective: In order to investigate Mg isotope fractionation during partial melting of garnet-bearing sources, we report Mg isotopic data of 17 well-characterized low-Mg adakitic rocks (LMA) from the Dabie orogen, central China.
challenges: Whether partial melting of these garnet-bearing sources can lead to significant Mg isotope fractionation or not remains poorly understood.
methods: Mg isotopic analyses were performed at the Isotope Geochemistry Laboratory of China University of Geosciences, Beijing, following procedures previously published. Approximately 2–10 mg sample powders containing about 20μgMg were dissolved using a 3:1 mixture of concentrated HF-HNO3. The dissolved samples were evaporated and then refluxed by a concentrated HCl-HNO3 mixture (3:1) and concentrated HNO3 stepwisely. Samples were dissolved in 1N HNO3 prior to the column chemistry. Magnesium was purified using the ion exchange resin AG50W-X8 (Bio-Rad 200–400 mesh) in a 1N HNO3 medium following the procedure outlined in Teng et al. (2007) and Ke et al. (2016). The same column procedure was processed twice to obtain a pure Mg solution. Magnesium isotopic ratios were measured on a Neptune Plus MC-ICP-MS in a low mass resolution mode by standard-sample bracketing. The standard-sample sequence was repeated 4 times for each sample.
dataset: Seventeen Dabie LMA were selected for Mg isotopic analysis, locating in Liangshan, Shangcheng, Lidian, Datong, Egongbao, Yunfengding and Zhangbang plutons. These LMA are relatively fresh and mainly have granular textures with medium-coarse minerals. Rock-forming minerals consist of quartz, K-feldspar, plagioclase, biotite and hornblende, except for those from Liangshan. The Liangshan samples have no hornblende, and biotite as the dominant Mg carrier has suffered sericitization and chloritization.
findings: Fresh Dabie LMA display nearly homogeneous Mg isotopic compositions, with an average δ26Mg of−0.22 ± 0.08‰ (2SD, N = 18), comparable to local mafic basement. The lack of correlation between δ26Mg and (Dy/Yb) N indicates an unresolvable residual garnet effect on Mg isotope fractionation during partial melting of thickened lower continental crust. Modelling suggests that Mg isotope fractionation factor between the melt and clinopyroxene (Δ26Mgmelt-cpx) is limited to be around −0.02‰. Compared to highly variable δ26Mg (−5.57‰ to +0.92‰) of supracrustal materials, isotope fractionation during partial melting of basaltic sources is either insignificant (< 0.14‰) in a thickened crust scenario or can be easily erased by melt-mantle interaction in a slab melting scenario. In this regard, Mg isotopes can serve as a powerful tracer of recycled supracrustal materials.

Disjunctive.Question: What is the main challenge in understanding Fe isotope fractionation during crustal melting: source heterogeneity, difficulty reconstructing parental magma composition, or the complexity of Fe isotope behavior?

Concept Completion.Question: Where are the samples for isotopic analysis in the Dabie orogen collected from?
Concept Completion.Answer: Liangshan, Shangcheng, Lidian, Datong, Egongbao, Yunfengding, Zhangbang plutons

Concept Completion.Question: What challenges are associated with reconstructing source properties for felsic igneous rocks during isotopic studies?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to analyze metal stable isotope data for Cretaceous rock bodies in orogenic belts?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method used to analyze metal stable isotope data for Cretaceous rock bodies in orogenic belts involves the use of Multi-Collector Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry (MC-ICPMS) for obtaining high precision measurements of metal stable isotopes such as Ca, Mg, and Fe, with accuracy typically better than 0.06‰.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in understanding iron isotope fractionation during crustal partial melting of felsic igneous rocks?
Example.Answer: An example of a challenge in understanding iron isotope fractionation during crustal partial melting of felsic igneous rocks is the difficulty in reconstructing the source properties and parental magma compositions, considering the complexity of fractionation behavior during processes like fractional crystallization and melt extraction.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of data collection methods used to measure metal stable isotopes in geological samples?
Feature Specification.Answer: precision within 2%, precision within 5%, precision generally better than 0.06‰

Quantification.Question: How many samples were analyzed for Fe isotopic data in the migmatite dataset from the Dabie orogen?
What is the total number of Early Cretaceous granitoid samples analyzed for Fe isotopic composition from the Dabie orogen and Central America?
How many Dabie LMA samples were selected for Mg isotopic analysis?

Definition.Question: What is the significance of using X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) in the context of elemental analysis in geological datasets?
Definition.Answer: X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) is used for testing major elements with a precision of within 2%. It provides important data that help in understanding the composition of geological samples, such as those from the Dabie orogen, which are crucial for analyzing metal stable isotope fractionation in magmatic systems.

Definition.Question: What does 'multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICPMS)' mean in relation to isotope analysis?
Definition.Answer: Multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICPMS) is a technique used to measure metal stable isotopes, such as Ca, Mg, and Fe, with a precision generally better than 0.06‰. This method is essential for obtaining high precision isotopic data, which are used to investigate isotope fractionation during geological processes like crustal melting and partial melting.

Comparison.Question: How does the precision of Fe isotopic data collection using MC-ICPMS compare to Mg isotopic data collection methods in terms of reproducibility and accuracy?
Comparison.Answer: Both Fe and Mg isotopic data are collected using MC-ICPMS, with Fe isotopic analysis reporting a long-term external reproducibility and accuracy better than ±0.03 ‰ (2SD), while Mg isotopic analysis reports an average δ26Mg of −0.22 ± 0.08‰ (2SD). Both methods emphasize high precision but may differ in their specific procedural details and isotope fractionation considerations.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in data collection techniques for elemental analysis using XRF compared to stable isotope analysis using MC-ICPMS within the context of the Dabie orogen datasets?
Comparison.Answer: XRF is used for major element analysis with a precision within 2%, focusing on bulk compositional data, whereas MC-ICPMS is used for stable isotope analysis with a precision better than 0.06‰, targeting isotopic ratios. The two methods cater to different analytical needs, with XRF providing elemental concentrations and MC-ICPMS offering detailed isotopic compositions.

Interpretation.Question: What insights can be drawn from the variability in elemental isotopic data regarding the processes of crustal melting and magma differentiation in orogenic belts?
Interpretation.Answer: The variability in elemental isotopic data, such as Fe and Mg isotopes, can reveal information about isotopic fractionation during crustal melting and magma differentiation. For example, differences in δ56Fe values between leucosomes and melanosomes can indicate the fractionation behavior and bonding conditions in granitic melts and their residual mafic minerals. Similarly, the near-homogeneity of Mg isotopic compositions in low-Mg adakitic rocks suggests limited fractionation during partial melting of basaltic sources.

Interpretation.Question: What challenges in reconstructing source compositions for felsic igneous rocks can be inferred from the complexity of Fe isotope fractionation behavior?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges in reconstructing source compositions for felsic igneous rocks can be inferred from the complexity of Fe isotope fractionation behavior, which involves multiple processes like fractional crystallization and melt extraction. The difficulty lies in distinguishing the effects of source heterogeneity and parental magma compositions due to the overlapping influences of redox conditions and mineral coordination environments on Fe isotopic variations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the precision of isotopic measurements in datasets related to the Dabie orogen's migmatites and granitoids?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The precision of isotopic measurements in the datasets related to the Dabie orogen's migmatites and granitoids is influenced by the use of high-resolution modes of MC-ICPMS, the standard-sample bracketing method, and thorough chromatographic purification processes. The precision is also maintained by conducting repeated measurements and considering both chemical procedures and isotopic measurement uncertainties.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why are specific data collection methods, such as the use of XRF and ICP-MS, preferred for analyzing elemental and isotopic compositions in Dabie orogen's rock samples?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The use of XRF and ICP-MS is preferred for analyzing elemental and isotopic compositions in Dabie orogen's rock samples due to their high precision levels. XRF provides accuracy within 2% for major elements, while ICP-MS offers precision within 5% for trace elements. The MC-ICPMS further ensures precision better than 0.06‰ for metal stable isotopes, making these methods suitable for detailed geochemical analyses.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the use of multiple isotopic measurement sequences impact the reliability of Mg and Fe isotopic data in geological studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of multiple isotopic measurement sequences can significantly enhance the reliability of Mg and Fe isotopic data by minimizing analytical uncertainties and improving accuracy. This can lead to more precise estimates of isotopic compositions and fractionation factors, aiding in the investigation of geological processes such as partial melting and magma differentiation.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the objectives behind collecting iron isotopic data from migmatites in the Dabie orogen to understand isotope fractionation during crustal anatexis?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The objective is to constrain isotope fractionation during crustal anatexis by reporting high precision Fe isotopic data for migmatites from the Dabie orogen, which helps in understanding the Fe isotopic variations related to processes such as fluid influx, crystallization, and mineral accumulation.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to investigate the effect of source mineralogy on iron isotope fractionation during partial melting using adakitic rocks?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Investigating the effect of source mineralogy on Fe isotope fractionation during partial melting of adakitic rocks helps to provide constraints on how different mineral compositions, especially garnet-bearing sources, affect isotope fractionation, offering insights into the redox conditions and magma differentiation processes.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the goal of analyzing magnesium isotopic compositions in low-Mg adakitic rocks from the Dabie orogen?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The goal is to investigate Mg isotope fractionation during partial melting of garnet-bearing sources, which can help in understanding the isotopic signatures of recycled supracrustal materials and the effects of residual garnet during the melting processes in thickened crust scenarios.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the specific procedures used in the Isotope Geochemistry Lab to purify and measure Fe isotopes using MC-ICPMS?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The Isotope Geochemistry Lab uses concentrated HF-HNO3-HCl-HClO4 to dissolve sample powders containing Fe, which is then purified using AG1X-8 resin in a HCl medium. The purified Fe is measured on a Neptune Plus MC-ICPMS using a sample-standard bracketing method, and the isotopic data are reported in traditional δ values relative to IRMM-014.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How is Mg isotope analysis conducted to ensure accurate fractionation measurement in geological samples?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Mg isotopic analyses are conducted by dissolving sample powders in a mixture of concentrated HF-HNO3, followed by refluxing with concentrated HCl-HNO3. The dissolved samples undergo purification using AG50W-X8 resin in a 1N HNO3 medium. Magnesium isotopic ratios are measured on a Neptune Plus MC-ICP-MS in low mass resolution mode by standard-sample bracketing.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have enabled the precise measurement of Fe isotope fractionation in igneous rocks?
Enablement.Answer: The use of multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICPMS) coupled with sample-standard bracketing has enabled the precise measurement of Fe isotope fractionation in igneous rocks, allowing for accuracy better than ±0.03‰ (2SD) as reported in the field.

Expectation.Question: Why might the expected variations in Fe isotope fractionation during crustal melting be challenging to capture in a dataset?
Expectation.Answer: The challenge in capturing expected variations in Fe isotope fractionation during crustal melting lies in the difficulty of reconstructing the source property and parental magma compositions for felsic igneous rocks, considering the complexity of Fe isotope fractionation behavior during processes such as fractional crystallization after melt extraction.

Expectation.Question: What reasons could account for the lack of significant Mg isotope fractionation observed in datasets of partial melting of garnet-bearing sources?
Expectation.Answer: The lack of significant Mg isotope fractionation in datasets of partial melting of garnet-bearing sources may be due to the limited Mg isotope fractionation factor between the melt and clinopyroxene, which is suggested to be around −0.02‰, indicating that any isotope fractionation during partial melting is either insignificant or can be erased by melt-mantle interaction.

Judgmental.Question: How do you evaluate the effectiveness of using X-ray fluorescence (XRF) and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) methods for data collection in the analysis of major and trace elements in geological samples?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of X-ray fluorescence (XRF) for major element analysis and inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) for trace elements in geological samples is highly effective due to their precision levels, with XRF having a precision within 2% and ICP-MS within 5%. These methods provide reliable and accurate data essential for understanding elemental compositions in geological research.

Judgmental.Question: What are the challenges associated with reconstructing the source property and parental magma compositions for felsic igneous rocks using current isotope fractionation methods?
Judgmental.Answer: Reconstructing the source property and parental magma compositions for felsic igneous rocks presents challenges mainly due to the complexity of iron isotope fractionation behavior. This complexity arises during processes such as fractional crystallization and melt extraction, making it difficult to accurately assess source properties.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, what are the potential benefits of using multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICPMS) for measuring metal stable isotopes in geological research?
Judgmental.Answer: The use of multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICPMS) for measuring metal stable isotopes offers significant benefits, including high precision, generally better than 0.06‰. This precision is crucial for accurately understanding metal stable isotope fractionation behaviors in magmatic systems, contributing valuable insights into geological processes.

Assertion.Question: I’m unsure about the challenges faced in reconstructing source properties and parental magma compositions for felsic igneous rocks.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges include the complexity of iron isotope fractionation behavior during processes like fractional crystallization after melt extraction and the difficulty in accurately reconstructing the original source properties and compositions of parental magmas.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of the role different geological environments play in affecting Fe isotope fractionation during partial melting processes.
Assertion.Answer: Geological environments, such as garnet-rich sources in eclogitic rocks, can lead to significant Fe isotope fractionation due to differences in source mineralogy. The environment plays a role in the extent of fractionation observed, with factors like redox conditions and coordination environment contributing to these variations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the data collection methods used for measuring metallic stable isotopes in the Dabie orogen and discuss the precision levels achieved through these techniques.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection methods for measuring metallic stable isotopes in the Dabie orogen involved using multi-collector inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (MC-ICPMS). The precision achieved for Ca, Mg, and Fe metallic stable isotopes was generally better than 0.06‰. This high precision was crucial for understanding the fractionation behavior of metallic stable isotopes in magmatic systems.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an overview of the challenges faced in reconstructing the source properties and parental magma compositions for felsic igneous rocks, and how these challenges affect the understanding of isotopic fractionation.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in reconstructing source properties and parental magma compositions for felsic igneous rocks include the complexity of iron isotope fractionation behavior during processes such as fractional crystallization after melt extraction. These challenges affect the understanding of isotopic fractionation by making it difficult to accurately trace the source and differentiation history of the rocks, thus complicating interpretations of isotopic variations.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify potential datasets that could be expanded or refined to improve understanding of isotope fractionation during partial melting and magma differentiation within the Dabie orogen.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for expansion or refinement include isotopic data from migmatites and adakitic rocks in the Dabie orogen. These datasets could be improved by increasing the number of samples analyzed, incorporating additional isotopic systems, or using more refined analytical techniques to enhance the understanding of isotope fractionation during partial melting and magma differentiation.
